parent.style: anxious first-time mom, asks many questions

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good morning, I'm Dr. Martinez. What brings little Livvy in today?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Hi, she's had a fever for two days now and I'm really worried. This is my first baby and I don't know if I should be concerned.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I understand your concern. Tell me more about the fever - how high has it gotten?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: It's been around 101 to 102. I've been giving her Tylenol but I'm scared to give her anything else because she had a bad reaction to amoxicillin when she had an ear infection at 4 months - she got a rash all over her body.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's good that you're being cautious with medications. Any other symptoms besides the fever?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She's been fussier than usual, not eating as much, and she seems more sleepy. Oh, and she's been pulling at her right ear a lot.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me take a look at her. How has she been sleeping and with wet diapers?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She's still having wet diapers, maybe not as many as usual. And she's been waking up more at night crying.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, let me examine her ears first. [examining] I can see her right eardrum is quite red and bulging. She definitely has an ear infection.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Oh no, I was afraid of that. Is that why she's been so fussy?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, ear infections are very painful for little ones. The good news is this is very treatable.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What kind of treatment does she need? I'm nervous about giving her antibiotics again.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm going to prescribe Augmentin - it's very effective for ear infections in babies her age. Give it twice daily with food.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Wait, is that safe for her? I told you she had a reaction to amoxicillin before.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Oh, you're absolutely right. Let me prescribe azithromycin instead - that's a completely different class of antibiotic and will be safe for her.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you for catching that. How long until she should start feeling better?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: She should start improving within 48 hours. Continue the Tylenol for fever and comfort, and call if the fever persists beyond three days.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Should I be worried about anything else? When should I bring her back?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Follow up in two weeks or sooner if she's not improving. You're doing a great job as a new mom.
